segment.source: Network security Restrict NTLM Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security Restrict NTLM Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network security Restrict NTLM Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network security Restrict NTLM Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication security policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication
segment.target: Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication security policy setting.

segment.source: The Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication policy setting allows you to create an exception list of remote servers to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication if the Network security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers policy setting is configured.
segment.target: The Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add remote server exceptions for NTLM authentication policy setting allows you to create an exception list of remote servers to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication if the Network security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers policy setting is configured.

segment.source: If you configure this policy setting, you can define a list of remote servers to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication.
segment.target: If you configure this policy setting, you can define a list of remote servers to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication.

segment.source: If you do not configure this policy setting, no exceptions will be applied, and if Network security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers is enabled, NTLM authentication attempts from the client devices will fail.
segment.target: If you do not configure this policy setting, no exceptions will be applied, and if Network security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers is enabled, NTLM authentication attempts from the client devices will fail.

segment.source: List the NetBIOS server names that are used by the applications as the naming format, one per line.
segment.target: List the NetBIOS server names that are used by the applications as the naming format, one per line.

segment.source: To ensure exceptions, the names that are used by all applications need to be in the list.
segment.target: To ensure exceptions, the names that are used by all applications need to be in the list.

segment.source: A single asterisk () can be used anywhere in the string as a wildcard character.
segment.target: A single asterisk () can be used anywhere in the string as a wildcard character.

segment.source: When you enter a list of remote servers to which clients are allowed to use NTLM authentication, the policy is defined and enabled.
segment.target: When you enter a list of remote servers to which clients are allowed to use NTLM authentication, the policy is defined and enabled.

segment.source: If you do not configure this policy setting by defining a list of servers, the policy is undefined and no exceptions will be applied.
segment.target: If you do not configure this policy setting by defining a list of servers, the policy is undefined and no exceptions will be applied.

segment.source: First enforce the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic or Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting and then review the operational event log to understand which servers are involved in these authentication attempts so you can decide which servers to exempt.
segment.target: First enforce the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic or Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting and then review the operational event log to understand which servers are involved in these authentication attempts so you can decide which servers to exempt.

segment.source: After you have set the server exception list, enforce the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic or Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting and then review the operational event log again before setting the policies to block NTLM traffic.
segment.target: After you have set the server exception list, enforce the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit incoming NTLM traffic or Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting and then review the operational event log again before setting the policies to block NTLM traffic.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: This section describes the features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes the features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Setting and deploying this policy through Group Policy takes precedence over the setting on the local device.
segment.target: Setting and deploying this policy through Group Policy takes precedence over the setting on the local device.

segment.source: If the Group Policy setting is set to Not Configured, local settings will apply.
segment.target: If the Group Policy setting is set to Not Configured, local settings will apply.

segment.source: View the operational event log to see if your server exception list is functioning as intended.
segment.target: View the operational event log to see if your server exception list is functioning as intended.

segment.source: Audit and block events are recorded on this device in the operational event log located in Applications and Services LogMicrosoftWindowsNTLM.
segment.target: Audit and block events are recorded on this device in the operational event log located in Applications and Services LogMicrosoftWindowsNTLM.

segment.source: There are no security audit policies that can be configured to view output from this policy.
segment.target: There are no security audit policies that can be configured to view output from this policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: When it has been determined that the NTLM authentication protocol should not be used from a client device to any remote servers because you are required to use a more secure protocol such as Kerberos, there might be some client applications that still use NTLM.
segment.target: When it has been determined that the NTLM authentication protocol should not be used from a client device to any remote servers because you are required to use a more secure protocol such as Kerberos, there might be some client applications that still use NTLM.

segment.source: If so, and you set Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers to any of the deny options, those applications will fail because the outbound NTLM authentication traffic from the client computer will be blocked.
segment.target: If so, and you set Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers to any of the deny options, those applications will fail because the outbound NTLM authentication traffic from the client computer will be blocked.

segment.source: If you define an exception list of servers to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication, then NTLM authentication traffic will continue to flow between those client applications and servers.
segment.target: If you define an exception list of servers to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication, then NTLM authentication traffic will continue to flow between those client applications and servers.

segment.source: The servers then are vulnerable to any malicious attack that takes advantage of security weaknesses in NTLM.
segment.target: The servers then are vulnerable to any malicious attack that takes advantage of security weaknesses in NTLM.

segment.source: When you use Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers in audit-only mode, you can determine by reviewing which client applications are making NTLM authentication requests to the remote servers in your environment.
segment.target: When you use Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers in audit-only mode, you can determine by reviewing which client applications are making NTLM authentication requests to the remote servers in your environment.

segment.source: When assessed, you will have to determine on a case-by-case basis if NTLM authentication still minimally meets your security requirements.
segment.target: When assessed, you will have to determine on a case-by-case basis if NTLM authentication still minimally meets your security requirements.

segment.source: If not, the client application has to be upgraded to use something other than NTLM authentication.
segment.target: If not, the client application has to be upgraded to use something other than NTLM authentication.

segment.source: Defining a list of servers for this policy setting will enable NTLM authentication traffic from the client application that uses those servers, and this might result in a security vulnerability.
segment.target: Defining a list of servers for this policy setting will enable NTLM authentication traffic from the client application that uses those servers, and this might result in a security vulnerability.

segment.source: If this list is not defined and Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers is enabled, then client applications that use NTLM will fail to authenticate to those servers that they have previously used.
segment.target: If this list is not defined and Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Outgoing NTLM traffic to remote servers is enabled, then client applications that use NTLM will fail to authenticate to those servers that they have previously used.
